subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Let the godly sing with joy to the Lord, for it is fitting to praise Him. (Ps 33:1)
reflection: Adoration, when it has entered God's presence and had fellowship with Him, will ever lead to the praise of His name. We should let praise be a part of the incense we bring before God in our quiet time. In the Psalms we see what a large place praise ought to have in the spiritual life. There are more than sixty Psalms of praise, becoming more frequent as the book draws to its close. We should study the Psalms more closely until our whole heart and life are one continual song of praise.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, in my quiet time with You may I always offer a heart filled with unceasing praise. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: And God said, "Let us make man in our own image, after our likeness." (Gen. 1:26)
reflection: Here we have the first thought of man, his origin and his destiny entirely divine. In this verse we see that God undertook the work of making a creature, who is not God, but to be a perfect likeness of Him in His divine glory. (how do you measure up?) Man was to live in entire dependence on God and to receive directly and unceasingly from God Himself the overflow of all that is holy and blessed in the Divine Being. (are you living up the God's requirements?) God' glory, His holiness, and His love were to dwell in man and shine out through him. (not doing so well are you?) Well don't fret, your not alone, neither am I or anyone else for that matter. After sin had done its terrible work, it spoiled the image of God. But a promise was given in Paradise that the seed of a woman would bring forth the Divine purpose, "God's Son" He would become a Son of Man, in whom God's plan would be carried out, His image in human form. Now between the eternal purpose and its eternal realization, we have a wonderful promise in regard to our life here on earth."We all, beholding the glory of the Lord, are changed into the same image, from glory to glory, as by the Spirit of the Lord". (2 Cor. 3:18)
prayer: Pray that God would keep our heart set upon the glory of the image of God in Christ Jesus, with the assurance that the Spirit will change us into His image day by day, from glory to glory. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: he Lord appeared to Abraham. and said to him: "I am God Almighty: Walk before Me, and be thou perfect. And I will multiply thee exceedingly." (Gen. 16:1-2)
reflection: In Abraham we see how God not only asks for faith and rewards faith, but also how He works faith by the gracious training that He gives. When God first called Abraham, He at once gave the great promise, "In thee shall all the families of the earth be blessed" (Gen. 12:3). When he reached the land, God met him with the promise that the land should be his (Gen. 12:7). When Abraham returned from the battle against the kings, God again met him to renew the promise (Gen. 5:15). Before the birth of Isaac, in the words of our text, God is seeking to strengthen his faith (Gen. 17). And once more in the plains of Mamre, God Spoke: "Is anything to hard for the Lord?" Step by step God led him until his faith was perfected for full obedience in the sacrifice of Isaac. As "by faith Abraham obeyed to go out, " so by faith at the close of forty years he was able, without any promise, in fact in apparent conflict with all the promises, to obey God's will to the very end. So, only can we go out like Abraham when we are called to a life of true consecration to God and in the obedience of faith. So let us walk in the foot steps of Abraham. Let us hide deep in our heart the testimony of God's Word: "He was strong in faith, giving glory to God; being fully persuaded, that what He had promised, He was able to perform."
prayer: Lets pray that the Lord would teach us the power of faith and all that He is willing to work in us who believe. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with ALL thine heart, and with ALL thy soul and with ALL thy might" (Deut. 6:5)
reflection: God taught Abraham what it was to believe in God with all his heart; he was strong in faith, giving glory to God. Moses taught Israel what the first great commandment was: to love God with all your heart. If we learn this commandment all the others will naturally follow. Through this Great Commandment our relationship with God as the loving Creator and man made in His image will be the object of that love. As Christians we should find our life, our destiny, and our happiness in just one thing, loving God with all our heart and with all our strength. Moses said: "The Lord has a delight in thy fathers, to love them." (Deut. 10:15) Let us learn a double Lesson. This perfect heart, loving God with all our might, is what God claims, is what God is infinitely worthy of, is what God will Himself give and work in us. A Prayer Suggestion: Let us pray that our whole soul go out in faith to meet - to wait for - and to expect the fulfillment of the promise - to love God with the whole heart. (This is what God Himself will work in us if we allow Him).
prayer: Let us pray that our whole soul go out in faith to meet - to wait for - and to expect the fulfillment of the promise - to love God with the whole heart. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "I will make a new covenant with the house of Israel. I will put My law in their inward parts, and in their hearts I will write it." (Jer. 31:31, 33)
reflection: When God made the first covenant with Israel at Sinai, He said, "If you will obey my voice indeed, and keep My covenant then you shall be a peculiar treasure unto Me among all peoples." (Ex. 19:5) I had never given this any thought before, but Israel really didn't have the power to obey. Why? Because their whole nature was carnal and sinful. In that first covenant there was no provision for the grace that should make them obedient. The law only served to show them their sin. Now in our text God promises to make a new covenant in which provision would be made to enable men to live a life of obedience. How? Because in this new covenant, the law was to be put in their inward parts and written in their heart, "not with ink, but with the Spirit of the living God." The lesson to be learned from the "new covenant" is that God's mighty power will be shown in the heart of everyone who believes the promise: "They shall not depart from me, " "It shall be given so as it has been spoken unto Me."
prayer: As you bow in deep stillness before God, pray that you will believe what He says. The belief in God's power will assist you in remaining faithful. Pray that the Lord Jesus would keep you "unblamable in holiness." Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "Call unto Me, and I will answer thee, and will show thee great things, and difficult which thou knowest not" (Jer. 33:3) "I the Lord have spoken it, and I will do it. For this moreover will I be inquired of by the house of Israel, to do it for them." (Ezek. 36:36-37)
reflection: The fulfillment of the great promises of the new covenant is made dependent on prayer. In answer to the prayer of Jeremiah, God had said: "I will put my fear in their hearts, that they shall not depart from Me." And to Ezekiel He had spoken: "I will cause them to walk in My statutes, and ye shall keep My judgments." To us in our unbelief and our judging of the meaning of God's Word according to human thoughts and experience, there is no expectation of these promises being truly fulfilled. We do not believe that God means them to be literally true. We do not have the faith in the mighty power of God that is waiting to make His promise true in our experience. Have we forgotten that God has said that without faith, our experience will be but very partial and very limited? God has very graciously point out the way in which such faith can be found. It is in the path of much prayer."Call unto Me, and I will answer thee, and show thee great things and difficult, which thou knowest not." It is when we turn to God individually with our whole heart to plead these promises that He will fulfill them.
prayer: Pray as the one who came to Jesus for help "Lord I believe, Help my unbelief." Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "For I will be merciful to their iniquities, and their sins will I remember no more." Heb. 8:12)
reflection: In this Epistle Christ is called the Mediator of a better covenant enacted upon better promises. (8:6) In Him the two parts of the covenant find their complete fulfillment. First of all, He came to atone for sin so that its power over man was destroyed and free access to God's presence and favor was secured. And with that came the fuller blessing, the new heart, freed from the power of sin, with God's Holy Spirit breathing into it the delight in God's law and the power to obey it. These two parts of the covenant may never be separated. And yet, how many there are who put their trust in Christ for the forgiveness of sin and yet never think of claiming the fullness of the promise, the new heart, cleansed from sin, with the Holly Spirit breathing it in such love and delight in God's law and such power to obey, that they have access to the full blessing of the new covenant, being God's people and knowing Him as their God.
prayer: Dear Lord Jesus You are my Lord and Master, my heart and life are fully Yours. Amen.

verse: "Ye believe in God, believe also in Me." (Jn 14:1)

reflection: We often hear these questions: "How can I abide in Christ always?" "How can I live wholly for Him?" Instead of asking another human, make these questions your fervent prayer. prayer: Pray that the Holy Spirit will make possible what is beyond our human reach: loving You, keeping Your commandments, and abiding in Your love, then give thanks. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: All who believe are justified freely by God's grace through the redemption that came by Jesus Christ. (Ro. 3:24)
reflection: Justification comes full and complete, As the eye of faith is fixed upon Christ. BUT that is only the beginning. Gradually believers must begin to understand that they are at the same time born again, that they have Christ in them, and that their calling now is to abide in Christ, and let Christ abide and live and work in them. Most Christians strive, by holding fast their faith in justification, strengthening themselves for a life of gratitude and obedience. But we fail badly if we do not in full faith yield ourselves to Christ, to maintain His life in us. Oh yes many have learned from Abraham the first lesson, to believe in God who justifies the ungodly. But many have not gone on to the second great lesson, to believe in God who quickeneth the dead and daily renews that life through Christ who lives in them and in whose life alone there is strength and fullness of blessing. The Christian life must be "from faith to faith." The grace of pardon is but the beginning; growing in grace leads on to a fuller insight and experience of what it is to be in Christ, to live in Him, and to grow up in Him in all things as the Head.
prayer: Dear Lord, lead me to a fuller insight and experience of what it is to be in Christ. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "That life which I now live in the flesh, I live in faith, the faith which is in the Son of God, who love me and gave Him self up for me." (Gal. 2:20 R. V. )
reflection: Paul says that he no longer lives but that Christ lives in him, so the logical question one could ask, is what then is his part in living that life? Well he gives us the answer" "The life that I now live in the flesh is the life of faith in the Son of God, who loved me and gave Himself up for me. His whole life day after day and all day long, was an unceasing faith in the wonderful love that had given itself for him. Faith was and is the key. Faith was the power that possessed and permeated his whole being and his every action. Here we have the simple but full statement of what the secret of the Christian life is. It is not faith only in certain promises of God or in certain blessings that we receive from Christ. It is a faith that has got a vision of how entirely Christ gives Himself to the soul to be in the very deepest and fullest sense of the word, his life and all that it implies for every moment of the day. It is as essential as continuous breathing is to the support of our physical life. True faith rests on that infinite love in which Christ gave Himself wholly for us. Yes He loved us all, and He gave Himself for us all, and He wish to live in us all.
prayer: Dear Lord, reveal to me that inseparable union between Christ and me in which the consciousness of Christ's presence may become as natural to me as the consciousness of my own existence. Amen.

04/30/09~~~food for thought~~~Be more concerned with your character
than your reputation...

Our Bible Verse for Today:
"The God of all grace, who called you unto His eternal glory in Christ, 
shall Himself perfect, establish, strengthen you, after you have suffered
a little while." (I Pet. 5:10)

Our Lesson for Today:

We know how the Epistle to the Hebrews gathers up all its teaching in 
that wonderful promise, "the God of peace perfect you in every good 
work."

Peter does the same thing here: "The God of all grace perfect, stablish,
strengthen you." God Himself is to be the one object of our trust day by
day; as we think of our work, of our needs, of our life and all our hearts 
desire, YES God Himself must be the one object of our hope and trust...

So what now is our position to God? Do we feel that the first thought of
every day ought to be the humble placing of ourselves in His hands to
confess our absolute helplessness ~ do we yield ourselves in child-like
surrender to receive from Him the fulfillment of such promises as these:

"The God of peace perfect you in every good work."
"The God of all grace perfecting, stablishing, strengthening you"?

Let us meet God every morning and give Him time to reveal Himself
and to take charge of our life for the day.

By His grace may we awaken every morning to go out every morning
to do our work, humbly trusting in the word: "God shall Himself perfect 
you. The Lord will perfect that which concerns me."

Prayer Suggestion:
Help me to awaken every morning trusting in Your grace...

Pastor Al & Marcie Sather

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "Ye know that He was manifested to take away sins; and in Him is no sin. Whosoever abideth in Him sinneth not." (I Jn. 3:5-6)
reflection: In our text today John teaches how we can be kept from sinning: "He that abideth in Christ sinneth not." Though there is sin in our nature, the abiding in Christ, in whom there is no sin, does indeed free us from the power of sin and enables us day by day to live so as to please God. Let the soul that longs to be free from the power of sin take to heart these simple but far-reaching words: "In Him is no sin" and "Of God I am in Him." "He that establisheth us in Christ is God." As we seek to abide in Him in whom there is no sin, Christ will indeed live out His own life in us in the power of the Holy Spirit and fit us for a life in which we always do things that are pleasing in His sight.
prayer: Lord work in my heart according to your will all that is good, as I wait for Thee. Amen.
